claim.hypotheses: The correlation between Gini index (income inequality) and school-effect (Variance Component of the Intercept for math) is positive.
claim.hypotheses_location: Page 627, Section 'National Income, Income Inequality, and the Importance of Schools'
claim.statement: In countries that are poor and unequal, schools overall matter more for math achievement.

data.sample_size: Ranges from 1,778 in Tunisia to 8,140 in the United States as per Table A2
data.access_details: Data accessed through the TIMSS database and American Educational Research Journal
data.notes: Data includes extensive background information on students, principals, math and science teachers, and curriculum. There is variability in missing data across countries.

method.description: The study uses hierarchical linear models (HLM) to examine the relative and overall importance of schools in student achievement across countries with different income and inequality levels, complementing this with ordinary least squares (OLS) for comparison.
steps: Data preparation and cleaning, including mean imputation for some SES variables.
Conduct OLS to examine relative and overall contribution of schools using school fixed effects.
Employ HLM to partition variance in student performance into between and within school-levels.
Examine impact of country economic and inequality status on the role of schools.
method.models: Hierarchical Linear Modeling (HLM), Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)
method.outcome_variable: Student mathematics and science achievement test scores
method.independent_variables: Student SES, age, gender, self-confidence, and home possessions.
method.control_variables: Age, gender, self-confidence in the subject, time spent on homework, language spoken at home, and perception of school safety.
method.tools_software: Data analysis was performed using statistical software capable of running HLM models, specifics not stated.

results.summary: The results indicate that schools are more influential in explaining student mathematics and science achievement in countries that are economically poorer and have higher levels of inequality. The school effect relative to family effect is more significant in countries with greater income inequality.

numerical_results.value: Varies by country, the maximum 0.54 found.
Varies by country, the maximum 0.53 found.

steps: Load the TIMSS 2003 dataset for fourth-grade data.
Perform hierarchical linear modeling to evaluate the effect of schools versus family background on student math and science achievements.
Control for student and family background variables such as self-confidence, homework time, and language spoken at home.
Investigate the correlation between national income inequality (Gini index) and the variance component of the intercept for math achievement.
